questions.scenario: During a project execution, the project manager notices that the critical path has changed from the "Software Design" path to the "Regulatory Approval" path. This was not expected in the original schedule baseline.
questions.questionText: What is the first thing the project manager should do?
questions.correctAnswer: Analyze the cause of the delay in the regulatory path and evaluate the impact on the project's overall completion date.
distractors: Immediately notify the sponsor that the project will be delayed by the difference between the two paths.
Crash the "Software Design" path to try and regain its position as the critical path.
Submit a change request to the Change Control Board to revert the critical path to the original baseline.

answers.text: Analyze the cause of the delay in the regulatory path and evaluate the impact on the project's overall completion date.
Immediately notify the sponsor that the project will be delayed by the difference between the two paths.
Crash the "Software Design" path to try and regain its position as the critical path.
Submit a change request to the Change Control Board to revert the critical path to the original baseline.

remediation.coreLogic: Critical paths are dynamic. When the path shifts, the PM must first understand *why* (root cause) and *what* it means for the project (impact analysis) before taking corrective action.
remediation.pmiMindset: Proactive monitoring involves detecting shifts in the schedule model and performing analysis before communicating or acting.
remediation.theTrap: You cannot "request" a critical path change (Distractor 3); it is a mathematical result of the task durations and logic. Crashing the wrong path (Distractor 2) is a waste of resources.

questions.questionText: What is the best "Rule of Thumb" for the Project Manager to provide?
questions.correctAnswer: Stop when the work packages are small enough to be accurately estimated, assigned to a single person or team, and have clear completion criteria.
distractors: Stop when the WBS has at least five levels of hierarchy for every single branch.
Stop when every work package can be completed in exactly 40 hours.
Stop when you have reached the level of individual mouse-clicks or keystrokes for the software tasks.

answers.text: Stop when the work packages are small enough to be accurately estimated, assigned to a single person or team, and have clear completion criteria.
Stop when the WBS has at least five levels of hierarchy for every single branch.
Stop when every work package can be completed in exactly 40 hours.
Stop when you have reached the level of individual mouse-clicks or keystrokes for the software tasks.

remediation.coreLogic: The goal of decomposition is management and control. If you can estimate it, assign it, and track it, you've reached the right level.
remediation.pmiMindset: Fit-for-purpose planning. Don't over-plan (Distractor 3) or under-plan.
remediation.theTrap: While 8-80 hours is a "guideline," rigidly sticking to "exactly 40 hours" (Distractor 2) is impractical and inefficient.

questions.scenario: A project manager is establishing a financial tracking system for a construction project. The organization's accounting system tracks "Invoices Paid," but the project's performance is measured by "Work Completed" and "Material Committed." The project manager notices a significant lag between when work is done on-site and when it appears in the accounting reports.
questions.questionText: What should the project manager do to ensure accurate spend tracking for performance measurement?
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain a project-level shadow budget to track "accrued costs" (work performed but not yet paid) for EVM calculations.
distractors: Rely solely on the official accounting reports to avoid discrepancies between the project and corporate records.
Request the finance department to change their payment terms to match the project's work schedule.
Use the "Invoices Paid" as the Actual Cost (AC) in the Earned Value formulas to ensure consistency.

answers.text: Maintain a project-level shadow budget to track "accrued costs" (work performed but not yet paid) for EVM calculations.
Rely solely on the official accounting reports to avoid discrepancies between the project and corporate records.
Request the finance department to change their payment terms to match the project's work schedule.
Use the "Invoices Paid" as the Actual Cost (AC) in the Earned Value formulas to ensure consistency.

remediation.coreLogic: Earned Value Management requires the Actual Cost (AC) to represent the cost of the work performed, not just the cash paid. Accrual-based tracking is necessary.
remediation.pmiMindset: The project manager must distinguish between "Cash Flow" and "Project Performance" and ensure metrics are technically sound for decision-making.
remediation.theTrap: Using "Invoices Paid" when there is a lag will artificially inflate the CPI, leading to a false sense of project health.

questions.scenario: A monthly status report for a construction project shows a Cost Variance (CV) of -$100,000 and a Schedule Variance (SV) of -$50,000. The project manager's narrative states that the project is "slightly behind but recovering."
questions.questionText: What is the most important element missing from this status communication to make it actionable for the sponsor?

distractors: A more detailed list of every material purchase made during the reporting period to justify the cost overrun.
A comparison of the current project's performance to three other similar projects currently being run by the organization.
A request for the sponsor to personally visit the site and observe the work to understand the challenges.

answers.text: A root cause analysis of the variances and a specific, data-backed recovery plan including updated forecasts (EAC/VAC).
A more detailed list of every material purchase made during the reporting period to justify the cost overrun.
A comparison of the current project's performance to three other similar projects currently being run by the organization.
A request for the sponsor to personally visit the site and observe the work to understand the challenges.

remediation.coreLogic: Effective status reporting (WPR) must provide "decision-ready" information. This includes not just the variance numbers, but *why* they happened and *what* the impact will be at completion.
remediation.pmiMindset: PMs should use metrics to surface problems and then use their judgment and analysis to propose solutions.
remediation.theTrap: Raw data without analysis is "noise." A report that says "we are behind" without a plan is just bad news, not a status report.

remediation.pmiMindset: The PM must manage within organizational financial constraints, using schedule flexibility as a primary tool.

remediation.pmiMindset: Data-driven baselining. You can't improve what you haven't measured.

questions.scenario:
A project manager is calculating the critical path for a project.
Path A: 12 days
Path B: 15 days
Path C: 14 days
The project manager decides to crash an activity on Path B by 2 days.
questions.questionText: What is the new critical path and the new project duration?
questions.correctAnswer: The new critical path is Path C with a duration of 14 days.
distractors: The new critical path is Path B with a duration of 13 days.
The project duration remains 15 days because crashing Path B doesn't affect Path C.
The project duration becomes 12 days as Path A is now the shortest path.

answers.text: The new critical path is Path C with a duration of 14 days.
The new critical path is Path B with a duration of 13 days.
The project duration remains 15 days because crashing Path B doesn't affect Path C.
The project duration becomes 12 days as Path A is now the shortest path.

remediation.coreLogic: Path B was the critical path (15d). After crashing by 2 days, Path B becomes 13 days. Now, Path C (14d) is the longest path in the network, making it the new critical path.
remediation.pmiMindset: Understanding that the critical path can shift after any compression or delay is fundamental to schedule control.
remediation.theTrap: Focusing only on the path you crashed (Distractor 1) and ignoring the rest of the network is a common mistake.

remediation.theTrap: Sending the same report to everyone ignores the fact that a board of directors needs different data (strategic/financial) than a regulatory agency (technical compliance).

questions.scenario: A project manager is decomposing a WBS for a large-scale manufacturing plant. The "Assembly Line" branch of the WBS has been decomposed into five levels. The team lead for the assembly line suggests that they should add a sixth level of decomposition to track individual bolt-tightening tasks as work packages.
questions.questionText: What is the most likely risk of following the team lead's suggestion?
questions.correctAnswer: Inefficient management due to excessive detail and administrative overhead in tracking progress.
distractors: Violation of the 100% rule because individual tasks are not considered "deliverables."
Failure to identify the critical path because the work packages are too small to be sequenced.
Increased budget risk because the team lead is trying to "gold plate" the manufacturing process.

answers.text: Inefficient management due to excessive detail and administrative overhead in tracking progress.
Violation of the 100% rule because individual tasks are not considered "deliverables."
Failure to identify the critical path because the work packages are too small to be sequenced.
Increased budget risk because the team lead is trying to "gold plate" the manufacturing process.

remediation.coreLogic: Excessive decomposition (micro-management) leads to high administrative overhead and inefficiency. Work packages should be at a level that allows for effective control without becoming a burden. The 8-80 hour rule is a common guideline to avoid this.
remediation.pmiMindset: Practicality and efficient control. Decompose until the work can be estimated and managed, but no further.
remediation.theTrap: While more detail seems better for "tracking," it often leads to "analysis paralysis" or the team spending more time reporting than doing work.

questions.scenario: A project manager is estimating the duration of a software testing phase. Based on historical data from similar projects, the PM knows that it typically takes 1 hour of testing for every 10 lines of code. The current project has 50,000 lines of code.
questions.questionText: Which estimation technique is the project manager using?
questions.correctAnswer: Parametric Estimation
distractors: Analogous Estimation
Bottom-Up Estimation
Three-Point Estimation

answers.text: Parametric Estimation
Analogous Estimation
Bottom-Up Estimation
Three-Point Estimation

remediation.coreLogic: Parametric estimation uses a mathematical model based on historical data and project parameters (e.g., cost per square foot, hours per line of code) to calculate duration or cost.
remediation.pmiMindset: Understanding different estimation techniques allows the PM to choose the most appropriate one based on the level of detail and data available.
remediation.theTrap: Analogous estimation uses the total duration of a past project without the mathematical scaling. Bottom-up involves estimating individual tasks and summing them.

questions.scenario: A project status report shows the following: CPI = 0.95 and SPI = 1.05. The project is currently on the critical path for a high-priority product launch.
questions.questionText: What is the most likely cause of this performance data?
questions.correctAnswer: The project manager is likely "crashing" the schedule (e.g., using overtime or more expensive resources) to stay ahead of the launch deadline, resulting in higher costs.
distractors: The project is performing poorly in both areas because any index not equal to 1.0 indicates a failure in project control.
The team is "gold plating" the product by adding extra features that were not in the original scope, which is increasing both speed and cost.
The project manager is "fast-tracking" the project, which is saving money but increasing the risk of rework and delays.

answers.text: The project manager is likely "crashing" the schedule (e.g., using overtime or more expensive resources) to stay ahead of the launch deadline, resulting in higher costs.
The project is performing poorly in both areas because any index not equal to 1.0 indicates a failure in project control.
The team is "gold plating" the product by adding extra features that were not in the original scope, which is increasing both speed and cost.
The project manager is "fast-tracking" the project, which is saving money but increasing the risk of rework and delays.

remediation.coreLogic: SPI > 1.0 (ahead) and CPI < 1.0 (over budget) is a classic signature of crashing. You are spending money to buy time.
remediation.pmiMindset: PMs must be able to read the "story" behind the metrics to understand the trade-offs being made in project execution.
remediation.theTrap: Fast-tracking usually increases risk but doesn't necessarily increase direct costs as much as crashing (which uses more labor/resources).

questions.scenario: A project manager is overseeing the construction of a new chemical processing plant. During a site inspection, a safety officer discovers a conflict between the ventilation installation and the emergency fire suppression system. The contractor wants to proceed with the ventilation as planned to avoid a significant schedule penalty, but the safety officer insists this would violate local building codes.
questions.questionText: What conflict resolution technique should the project manager use in this specific instance?
questions.correctAnswer: Force / Direct the contractor to comply with the safety officer's requirements to ensure legal and safety compliance.
distractors: Collaborate with both parties to find a creative engineering solution that satisfies both the ventilation needs and the safety codes.
Compromise by allowing the ventilation installation to proceed if the contractor agrees to add additional fire sensors in other areas.
Smooth over the disagreement by emphasizing the shared goal of finishing the project on time and within budget.

answers.text: Force / Direct the contractor to comply with the safety officer's requirements to ensure legal and safety compliance.
Collaborate with both parties to find a creative engineering solution that satisfies both the ventilation needs and the safety codes.
Compromise by allowing the ventilation installation to proceed if the contractor agrees to add additional fire sensors in other areas.
Smooth over the disagreement by emphasizing the shared goal of finishing the project on time and within budget.

remediation.coreLogic: For issues involving safety, legal compliance, or severe emergencies, the Force/Direct technique is the only appropriate response. There is no room for negotiation when it comes to building codes and life safety.
remediation.pmiMindset: Force is generally discouraged EXCEPT in cases of safety, compliance, or emergencies. The PM must take immediate action to protect the project and the public.
remediation.theTrap: The action of collaborating sounds better because it's "Win-Win," but in a safety/compliance emergency, time and regulation dictate the outcome, not creative brainstorming.

questions.scenario: A project manager is analyzing the Variance at Completion (VAC). The BAC is $800,000, and the current EAC (Estimate at Completion) is $850,000. The project is 75% complete.
questions.questionText: What does this VAC status indicate, and what should be the PM's next step?
questions.correctAnswer: The VAC is -$50,000, indicating a projected budget overrun; the PM should communicate this to the sponsor and discuss if additional funding or scope reduction is needed.
distractors: The VAC is $50,000, indicating a healthy budget surplus that can be used to add more features to the project.
The project is on budget because the VAC is less than 10% of the total budget at completion.
The project manager should immediately release the management reserve to eliminate the $50,000 variance before the next reporting period.

answers.text: The VAC is -$50,000, indicating a projected budget overrun; the PM should communicate this to the sponsor and discuss if additional funding or scope reduction is needed.
The VAC is $50,000, indicating a healthy budget surplus that can be used to add more features to the project.
The project is on budget because the VAC is less than 10% of the total budget at completion.
The project manager should immediately release the management reserve to eliminate the $50,000 variance before the next reporting period.

remediation.coreLogic: VAC = BAC - EAC = 800,000 - 850,000 = -$50,000. A negative VAC indicates a projected overrun. The PM must escalate and address this with the sponsor.
remediation.pmiMindset: Transparency in financial forecasting is essential. Negative variances at 75% completion are difficult to recover and require governance-level decisions.
remediation.theTrap: Management reserves are for "unknown-unknowns" and usually require a change request to be incorporated into the baseline. They aren't just "pots of money" to hide performance issues.

questions.scenario: A project is planned to last four years and involves a significant amount of specialized steel. The global market for steel is currently volatile, and prices are expected to fluctuate significantly over the project duration. The project manager wants to use a fixed-price contract to lock in the vendor but recognizes that a standard firm-fixed-price contract might be too risky for the seller.
questions.questionText: Which contract type is BEST suited for this multi-year project?
questions.correctAnswer: Fixed Price with Economic Price Adjustment (FP-EPA)
distractors: Firm Fixed Price (FFP)
Fixed Price Incentive Fee (FPIF)
Cost Plus Incentive Fee (CPIF)

answers.text: Fixed Price with Economic Price Adjustment (FP-EPA)
Firm Fixed Price (FFP)
Fixed Price Incentive Fee (FPIF)
Cost Plus Incentive Fee (CPIF)

remediation.coreLogic: FP-EPA contracts are specifically designed for long-term projects where external economic factors (inflation, commodity prices) are beyond the control of both parties.
remediation.pmiMindset: Protect both the buyer and seller from external economic volatility in long-term agreements. This ensures the contract remains viable for the duration.
remediation.theTrap: A standard FFP would force the seller to include a massive "risk premium" in their price, making it unnecessarily expensive for the buyer.

questions.scenario: An agile team is consistently delivering its committed story points, but the customer is still unhappy during Sprint Reviews, stating that the features "don't feel right" for the end-users.

questions.scenario: A project manager is lead a team of 10 people. The project sponsor adds a new "Quality Assurance" layer, adding 4 more people to the communication loop. The sponsor is concerned that information flow is slowing down.

The vision of the project is too complex for a global team to understand.

remediation.pmiMindset: The PM is culturally aware. They look for ways to create a safe space for all voices to be heard, regardless of cultural background.
remediation.theTrap: Assuming a lack of competence (Distractor 1) is a common bias. Directing/forcing (Distractor 2) doesn't build a *shared* vision; it just builds compliance.

questions.scenario: A project manager receives a request from a senior engineer to modify the welding procedure specification to use a different filler metal. distractors: Allow the engineer to proceed with the change since they are the technical expert and the change improves efficiency

Escalate to the project sponsor to determine if the engineer has authority to make technical substitutions

Allow the engineer to proceed with the change since they are the technical expert and the change improves efficiency
Ask the quality manager to evaluate whether the filler metal substitution affects quality standards
Escalate to the project sponsor to determine if the engineer has authority to make technical substitutions

remediation.coreLogic: Configuration control extends to technical specifications and procedures. Even beneficial changes require formal analysis and approval when they affect baselined requirements. questions.scenario: A project manager is negotiating with a department head for the use of a specialized testing lab. questions.correctAnswer: Focusing on interests rather than positions to uncover the underlying concern.
distractors: Building a ZOPA (Zone of Possible Agreement) based on shared lab usage.
Improving the project's BATNA by looking for alternative testing facilities.
Using objective criteria to prove that the project has a right to the lab.

Building a ZOPA (Zone of Possible Agreement) based on shared lab usage.
Improving the project's BATNA by looking for alternative testing facilities.
Using objective criteria to prove that the project has a right to the lab.

remediation.coreLogic: The department head's *position* was "No access." Their *interest* was "Ensuring the lab remains clean and ready for their own work." By asking "why," the PM uncovered the interest.

remediation.theTrap: The action of looking for alternative facilities (BATNA) is a good backup, but the PM is currently in the middle of the negotiation itself, using interest-based tactics.

remediation.theTrap: Baselines are still needed (Distractor 1). Resources are usually not fully allocated 12 months out in R&D (Distractor 2). Rolling wave doesn't "prevent" scope creep; it just manages how we plan for it.

questions.scenario: A project manager is rolling out an agile project management tool (Jira) to a team that currently uses a whiteboard and sticky notes. The team loves their physical board and is resisting the digital tool, saying it adds overhead and reduces visibility.

questions.scenario: A project manager is reviewing the Issue Log for a global rollout. questions.scenario: A Scrum team discovers that a third-party library they've been using has a critical security vulnerability. The product owner wants to wait until the next sprint to address it because fixing it would delay the current sprint's commitment. The Scrum Master is concerned about the security risk of waiting 2 weeks with a known critical vulnerability in production.
questions.questionText: What is the BEST action for the Scrum Master to take?
questions.correctAnswer: Stop using the vulnerable library immediately, even if it means reducing the sprint commitment to address security
distractors: Continue using the library for this sprint and plan to fix it in the next sprint
Escalate to the product owner's manager to get approval for an immediate fix
Add the security fix as a high-priority item in the next sprint backlog

remediation.coreLogic: Critical security vulnerabilities are stop-work issues regardless of sprint commitments. Known vulnerabilities create immediate liability. The team stops using the vulnerable component now.
remediation.pmiMindset: Security and safety are non-negotiable. Sprint commitments don't override the obligation to address critical security issues immediately.
remediation.theTrap: Planning to fix in the next sprint treats this as normal prioritization, but critical vulnerabilities are immediate risks, not scheduled work items.
